description: This course provides a broad interdisciplinary overview of theories and research on human sexuality.
title: Introduction to Human Sexuality
prerequisites: Level at least 1B.
subject: SMF

description: As with all profound and meaningful human activities, sexuality has the potential to involve harm, manipulation, and abuse. This course will offer a theoretical and empirical examination of the dark side of human sexuality. Topics may include prostitution, pornography, sexual violence and abuse, incest, AIDS and STDs, paraphilias, and hate crimes.
title: The Dark Side of Sexuality
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236
subject: SMF

description: This course provides an overview of couple, marital, and family relationships from a broad, interdisciplinary perspective.
title: Couples, Marriages, and Families
prerequisites: Level at least 1B
subject: SMF

description: This course examines parent-child relationships from a broad interdisciplinary perspective. Topics may include voluntary childlessness, the transition to parenthood, single parenting, stepparenting, gay and lesbian parenting, and care of aging parents.
title: Parents, Children, and Family Relations
prerequisites: SMF 206
subject: SMF

description: This broad survey course introduces students to the theory and practice of both couple and family therapy and sex therapy.
title: Introduction to Couple, Family, and Sex Therapy
prerequisites: SMF 206; SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: This course introduces students to the philosophy and methods of social science and humanities research, including an examination of issues and approaches to conducting research in the areas of sexuality, couples, and families.
title: Research Methods
prerequisites: One of SMF 204, 206, PSYCH 236.
antirequisites: KIN 330, PSCI 315, PSYCH 291, REC 270, 270A, SOC/LS 321, SDS/SWREN 251R
subject: SMF

description: The goal of this introductory statistics course is to help students understand the logic and appropriate application of commonly used descriptive and inferential statistics, with examples drawn from various disciplines relevant to sexuality, marriage, and family studies.
title: Introduction to Statistics in Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Studies
prerequisites: SMF 220; One of SMF 204, 206, PSYCH 236.
antirequisites: ARTS 280, ECON 221, ENVS 278, KIN 222, PSCI 314, PSYCH 292, REC 371, SDS/SWREN 250R, SOC/LS 280, STAT 202, 206, 211, 221, 231, 241
subject: SMF

description: This course is an examination and analysis of the theories and methods of communication as applied within the processes of individual, relational, and family consultation and counselling.
title: Communication and Counselling Skills
prerequisites: One of SMF 204, 206, PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A.
subject: SMF

description: This course examines the development and experience of sexuality in a relational context from infancy to old age. Emphasis will be placed on sexual interaction and communication in adult relationships, but the effects of relationships on sexual experiences during infancy, childhood, adolescence, and old age may also be examined.
title: Human Sexuality in Relationships
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: This course will provide a detailed examination of selected issues and controversies in the area of human sexuality. Topics may include the role of sex education in schools, nature vs. nurture, censorship, and surrogate motherhood.
title: Social Issues and Controversies in Human Sexuality
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: The interpersonal dynamics involved in the formation and maintenance of close relationships will be examined. Topics such as attraction, commitment, love, trust, and communication will be examined from various theoretical and empirical perspectives.
title: The Formation and Maintenance of Close Relationships
prerequisites: One of SMF 206, PSYCH 220R, PSYCH 253/253R; Level at least 2A.
subject: SMF

description: Families and close relationships are among the most important and valued human experiences, but they can also be the source of much conflict and pain. This course will examine the dark side of close relationships, with a focus on topics such as conflict and conflict resolution, family violence, poverty, separation and divorce, illness, and death and bereavement.
title: Conflict, Crisis, and Dissolution in Close Relationships
prerequisites: One of SMF 206, PSYCH 220R, PSYCH 253/253R; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: Modern and postmodern therapeutic approaches to working clinically with couples and families are examined, with a focus on cultural sensitivity, social justice, and anti-oppression. Students will connect theory to practice, and implement family therapy and ethical skills.
title: Couple and Family Therapy
prerequisites: SMF 208, 220, 301; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: This course examines therapeutic approaches and clinical issues when working with sexuality related problems. Sexuality variation, and research and methodological issues in the field of sex therapy will be discussed from theoretical and applied perspectives. The applied focus enables students to connect clinical theory and ethical issues to practice.
title: Sex Therapy
prerequisites: SMF 208, 220, 301; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: A study of social relationships and structures that support sexual identities and generate issues related to sexual behaviour, attitudes, and values at the individual and group level.
title: Sexual Ethics
prerequisites: SMF 206, 220; SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2B
subject: SMF

description: This course is an examination and analysis of the theories and methods of communication as applied within the processes of individual, relational, and family consultation and counselling.
title: Communication and Counselling Skills
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A.
subject: SMF

description: This course introduces students to the history of Western sexuality, beginning with the ancient world and focusing primarily on the Middle Ages and the transition to modernity.
title: History of Sexuality: The Pre-Modern Period
prerequisites: At least one HIST course; Level at least 3A
subject: SMF

description: This seminar introduces students to the history of Western sexuality. The course focuses on the 19th and 20th centuries.
title: History of Sexuality: The Modern Period
prerequisites: At least one HIST course; Level at least 3A
subject: SMF

description: This course introduces students to special topics in the history of sexuality such as homosexuality, family, or erotica and pornography.
title: History of Sexuality: Special Topics
prerequisites: SMF 204 or any 200-level HIST course; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: A specialized course in sexuality topics. See the SMF Director for current offerings.
title: Special Topics in Human Sexuality
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: A specialized course in couples, marriage, and family topics. See the SMF Director for current offerings.
title: Special Topics in Couples, Marriage, and Family Studies
prerequisites: SMF 206; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: A specialized course that approaches topics of sexuality, marriage, and family from a humanities perspective. These integrated courses take a theoretical approach to the subject matter. See the SMF Director for current offerings.
title: Special Topics in Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Studies
prerequisites: SMF 204 or PSYCH 236, and SMF 206; Level at least 2A
subject: SMF

description: An independent, in-depth study, based on empirical research and/or extensive reading, of a topic in the area of sexuality. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to registration.
title: Independent Study: Special Topics in Sexuality
prerequisites: SMF 220, 230, 310; SMF 304 or 305; Level at least 3A
subject: SMF

description: An independent, in-depth study, based on empirical research and/or extensive reading, of a topic in the area of marriage and family. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to registration.
title: Independent Study: Special Topics in Marriage and Family Studies
prerequisites: SMF 220, 230, 310; one of SMF 306, 307, PSYCH 354; Level at least 3A
subject: SMF

description: An independent, in-depth study, based on empirical research and/or extensive reading, of a topic in the area of marriage and family therapy. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to registration.
title: Independent Study: Special Topics in Couple and Family Therapy
prerequisites: SMF 220, 230, 310; SMF 308 or 309; Level at least 3A
subject: SMF

description: This course involves an assigned unpaid apprenticeship in a human sexuality or family studies setting combined with regular seminar meetings. The practicum will require no more than ten hours per week. Paid or volunteer positions that are obtained outside the context of this course are not eligible for credit in this course.
title: Practicum and Professional Ethics
prerequisites: SMF 230, 310; Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Studies students only
subject: SMF

description: This course involves an assigned unpaid apprenticeship in a human sexuality or family studies setting combined with regular seminar meetings. The practicum will require no more than eight hours per week. Paid or volunteer positions that are obtained outside the context of this course are not eligible for credit in this course.
title: Practicum and Applied Theory
prerequisites: SMF 460; Honours Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Studies students only
subject: SMF

description: Under supervision of a faculty member, students normally will review literature, present an oral research proposal, analyze data, write a scholarly research paper, and deliver a seminar presentation based on the paper.
title: Research Thesis and Applied Theory
prerequisites: SMF 460; Honours Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Studies students only
subject: SMF

description: This seminar allows students to integrate their knowledge in the domain of sexuality, marriage, and family ethics. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.
title: Seminar in Sexuality, Marriage, and Family Ethics
prerequisites: SMF 230, 310; One of SMF 304, 305, 365; one of SMF 306, 307, 366, PSYCH 354; one of SMF/HIST317, SMF/HIST318, SMF 319; Level at least 3B
subject: SMF

description: This seminar allows students to integrate their knowledge in the domain of sexuality studies. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.
title: Seminar in Sexuality
prerequisites: SMF 230, 310; One of SMF 304, 305, 365; One of SMF/HIST 317, SMF/HIST 318, SMF 319; Level at least 3B
subject: SMF

description: This seminar allows students to integrate their knowledge in the domains of couples, marriages, and family studies. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.
title: Seminar in Family Studies
prerequisites: SMF 230, 310; One of SMF 306, 307, 366, PSYCH 354; Level at least 3B
subject: SMF

description: This seminar allows students to integrate their knowledge in the domain of couples, family, and sex therapy. Topics reflect current issues from a theoretical and research perspective.
title: Seminar in Therapy: Couple, Family, and Sex Therapy
prerequisites: SMF 230, 310; SMF 308 OR 309 Level at least 3B
subject: SMF
